We bring fine goods from faraway lands. Pray, what is it you seek?
Built near nomadic settlements they bring a steady trickle of gold and unusual items.
By bringing the tribes of Araby together we can muster a force the like of which has never been seen.
To earn a Giants trust takes time, food and gold but their results on the battlefield speak for themselves.
Arabyan troops are famous for their elite equipment and training. In the Kasbah, soldiers prepare for combat, while protecting crossing areas and merchant routes.
From their noble past to their downfall, the Blood Dragons relentlessly train. It is said, that even the fabled Grail Knights cannot match them lance for lance.
A collection of a few primitive huts, built by a tribe which has not yet completely given up their nomadic lifestyle.
Some basic infrastructure and a few sturdy houses, most likely inhabited by a lesser clan or small tribe.
Good leadership or a suitable location allowed this settlement to amass a certain amount of wealth and recognition.
An important settlement ruled by a clan, serving as a center of culture and commerce as well as an important military basis.
This city serves as the seat of a great clan. Such densely populated areas are relatively rare on Albion and therefore of great importance.

A single Ogham stone, binding the winds of magic and corrupting the lands for the benefit of the rest of the world.
A small circle of Ogham stones, more effective together than each of them would be on its own.
A medium-sized circle of Ogham stones, attracting magic from around the world and binding it to the earth of Albion, thus tainting fauna and flora.
A big circle of Ogham stones. Air and soil are saturated with magic, ready to be utilized by those with the required knowledge and ability.
Danu, the Earthmother, is the most worshipped goddess of the people of Albion. Shrines in her honor can be found in many villages around the island.
Bigger cities sometimes have temples at sacred sites where the power of the Earthmother is supposed to be strongest.
It is said that Danu herself blessed these places and that sometimes she can be witnessed to visit them in disguise.
A small, crudely scrambled together hut which serves as a basis of operation for local hunters.
A sturdy wooden building where hunters prepare for their next expedition into the dangerous wilds of Albion.
A grand hall displaying trophies of impressive hunts of the past. The best hunters meet here to practice their craft.
A place for the leaders of the tribe to gather and solve internal problems, sometimes through ritual combat.
The Chieftains and Elders meet to discuss questions of law. Young nobles and promising warriors are also trained in matters of tribal law.
The leaders of the most important local tribes meet here with their most capable advisors to avoid internal warfare - mostly without bloodshed.
A blacksmith is necessary to build the more advanced weapons used by the warriors of Albion.
Smithing is not as developed in Albion as it is in most of the more sophisticated civilizations, however, their craftsmen are still talented and can produce items of great worth and beauty.
An open field where warriors hone their skills in training duels.
A primitive but sturdy wooden structure in the heart of Albion settlements, where experienced warriors teach others in their craft.
The hall of an important chieftain where the elite of Albion's warriors gathers.
Barely more than a grassy field where the horses of the tribe are kept.
A wooden fence keeps the horses inside and the smaller predatory beasts of the wild out.
A wooden building shielding the cavalry from the harsh weather of the island.
Wooden fences barely slow down attackers, but they can buy the defenders some valuable moments to arm themselves.
Barricades made from wood and scrap metal to deter enemies from quick raids or infiltration.
A wooden palisade that will slow approaching enemy armies and give the defenders a small advantage in the fight.
This big building was built in honor of the heroes of past and present. Being allowed to feast and train within its walls is regarded as one of the highest honors.
Watchtowers have been erected to guard against threats for this exclave.
Warriors constantly patrol the perimeters in search of hostile activities.
The tactical value of this spot justified bringing experienced warriors and mighty monsters to prevent it from falling into enemy hands.

The elevated ground near an Albion settlement sometimes attracts members of the elusive Highlander tribes or Feral Gryphons which will defend their territory against the more dangerous chaos monsters of the islands.
Settlements with stony hills nearby are much better suited for chariot races and produce more charioteers than settlements with only swampy areas around.

The Maiden's Halls serve as a meeting point for women who want to pick up the art of war. Experienced Sword Maidens and Huntresses teach their craft here to young women eager to walk the way of the warrior.
Those women who serve the Oracle as guards and scouts are the most experienced female warriors of each tribe.

The very first and biggest of the Ogham Stone Circles. It took dozens of Giants many days to build it under the guidance of the Truthsayers and it binds more of the Winds of Magic than any other Ogham Circle to this day.

This mysterious and complex building was left behind when the Old Ones fled Albion. Generations of Truthsayers have attempted to uncover its mysteries, but all failed. The forge operates to this day and while much of its products are not understood nor utilized by the inhabitants of Albion, it remains one of the few reliable sources of wealth and culture on the island.

The might of the traitorous demon Bela'kor was supposedly sealed away by the Chaos Gods themselves in this appalling citadel. Whatever the truth may be, it can't be denied that this repulsive structure oozes energy which can elevate those foolhardy enough to use it to ever greater levels. The wise however know that such power doesn't come without cost and stay far away.

The long lost deep tunnels of Karak Azgal are known as Dragon Crag nowadays and have provided a comfortable home to Chief Ugma for most of his life. Many adventurers brave the dangers of the dungeon to restore the lost hold or simply to loot its still impressive riches. Their reasons matter little to Ugma as the steady stream of adventurers provides a never-ending source of meat, entertainment, wealth and the glittering trinkets Ugma loves so much.
Long buried and forgotten, some soldiers of the Dread King's own legions have been entombed here.
The most skilled and favoured guards of the Dread King have been kept dormant in their last resting place for centuries - until now.
We'll round up every miscreant we can get our hands on.
We'll turn over every tavern and ply them with beer until they sign.
You try negotiating with an Ogre!
The wandering Wizard has many oddities and trinkets in the back of his cart even a few fireworks.
A place for Wizards to make a little money on the side.
This horse-drawn alter encompasses of a Griffon effigy at its centre with fanatics often in tow.
It is wise to keep lookouts so you may choose the wisest paths and gain the greatest vantage points.
A central place for our scouts and hunters to rest and plan. It also includes a room to cure and hang the meat.
A network of small outposts means we are all ways one step ahead of our foes.
The Paymaster is nearly as important as the army's general being responsible for the mercenaries pay.
Blacksmiths only ever join the largest of camps to ensure a steady stream of income.
Traders ensure luxuries and other home comforts are available to the men, often at eye-watering prices.
A small basic camp with tents surrounding a roaring campfire.
Just large enough to require a few sentries dotted around the camp.
A large camp, where the clattering of steel and the many campfires can be heard and seen from afar.
Small towers, palisades and wagons are strategically placed to defend the burgeoning inhabitants.
Wagons arrange themselves into a circle along with any other defences thrown up in defence of the bustling camp.
Disused farmland turned into a makeshift place to treat the wounded and dying.
A glorified tent, still preferable to the open-air alternative.
This place has a bucket for the amputated limbs, fancy!
Little more than a small dusty camp.
A well-sized outpost, good for protecting the borderlands.
This could double for a small town, if you replaced all the townsfolk for ruffians.
A place for men to enlist, train and be formed into regiments.
So important is salt to the Halflings they categorize it by quality, with the finest salts used for fine cooking.
Demand is high for all salts and the Halflings are willing to lose life and limb in its pursuit.
They lick their lips at the huge mounds of salt produced and some Halflings have even been caught in the midst of unsavoury actions.
Heroes of damnation flock here to prove their might.
Not much more than a big hole to put the filthy slaves to work in.
The deeper the hole, the greater the reward, but also the risk. And when it's a slave's life on the line we can live with that, even if they can't...

It's not unusual to stumble upon a half-eaten, shriveled corpse of a slave. They complain we delved too greedily and too deep. That we awoke in the darkness ... shadow and flame. Good! Let its foulness join our ranks.
Goblins can be useful... sometimes.

Inside a forgotten rocky valley near the World's Edge Mountains lies the tomb of Karitamen, the Death Scarab himself, and deadly foe to Prince Fatandira and her people. The Liche Lord is conspicuously absent, but has left behind many riches and servants, ripe for the taking...
A place for the Golden Magus' many acolytes to study and display their sorcerous abilities.
Only the Magus' most trusted magical pupils are allowed to enter this part of the ship.
Being both a pleasure barge and a corsair ship, the Flaming Scimitar is only lightly armed with smaller bronze cannons, instead of the heavier artillery of other pirate ships.
From this lookout, the Magus' magician servants cast the most potent spells to aid his forces in battle.
The Minaret of Tempests is where the Golden Magus and his most powerful acolytes cast their strongest spells, directed at enemy forces.

Inside this awe-inspiring golden tower is where the source of the Golden Magus' powers resides. Hidden in it, in a location unknown to anyone but the Magus himself reside the 3 magical urns containing the fabled Royal Djinns, drained of their energies for the Magus' benefit.

...The Magus stood up, stretching like a cat in the morning sun. He would allow\\nhimself a break from the frenetically entertaining world of men for a while, perhaps,\\nand spend a little time as a king instead of a servant....
Barely more than a dirty hole in a hill where trolls naturally dwell.
A permanent troll abode, full of junk, bones and the aftermath of many troll meals.
A big gathering place for trolls. The stench is barely tolerable for every unfortunate soul that dares venture too close to it.
A huge bewildering maze that only the most daring adventurer would dare venture into.
